text.section:
Subject to § 4-506 of this subtitle, an anatomical gift may be made during the life of a donor for the purpose of transplantation, therapy, research, or education by:
A donor who is an adult; or
A donor who is a minor, if the minor is:
An agent of a donor, unless a power of attorney for health care or other record prohibits the agent from making an anatomical gift;
A parent of a donor, if the donor is an unemancipated minor; or
A guardian of a donor.

section.section:
A donor or other person authorized to make an anatomical gift under this section may make a gift by:
A donor card or other record signed by the donor or other person making the gift; or
Authorizing that a statement or symbol indicating that the donor has made an anatomical gift be included on a donor registry.

If a donor or other person authorized to make an anatomical gift under this section is physically unable to sign a record, the record may be signed by another individual at the direction of the donor or other person and shall:
Be witnessed by at least two adults, at least one of whom is a disinterested witness, who have signed at the request of the donor or other person; and
State that the record has been signed and witnessed as provided in item (i) of this paragraph.

text.section: Revocation, suspension, expiration, or cancellation of a driver's license or an identification card that indicates an anatomical gift does not invalidate the gift.

section.section: An anatomical gift made by will takes effect on the donor's death whether or not the will is probated.
If a will that makes an anatomical gift is invalidated after the donor's death, the anatomical gift does not become invalid.
